Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 26, 2011 11:00AM joyce1419 wrote: Hi, I had lumpectomy prior to chemo. I had mammogram  placement--and mammos are always painful for me--of the wire pre- lumpectomy and there was big needle of lidocaine for that   and i had radioactuve dye inserted via large neeedle into nipple after that for location of sentinel node.  i then had a painful, 30 minute over the head, don't move, with a sore shoulder period in order to take photos of the node. This was all pretty, very traumatic.  I told the staff recently that someone should have written standing orders for some relaxant, ativan type, and some pain meds taken before all of this. As rough as chemo has been, that presurgery will stay memorable.  If I had known more details beforehand about those pre-surgery procedures, I would have requested something.  But THEY should have better protocol to offer, and the RN agreed and said she would make that  suggestion.   By contrast, the surgery was a non-experience. Good luck.  I hope your experience is more tolerable.  Joyce
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 02:46PM joyce1419 wrote: I started chemo on Tuesday, so this is what is called day #3?  Doing AC q 2 wks x 4 then T q 2 weeks x 4.  Day one went ok, but I will need a central line port put in as veins poor for chemo though I had a good nurse do me that day.  I have been following this forum topic as so helpful for me to know what to expect and advice has been great.  I do have nausea which I hate and instead of taking the zofran prn i have switched to routine q 12 hours and feel so much better.  though it gives me a headache. and that i can deal with.  i like the energy burst of the steroids but it is deceptive and eventually feels like bad diet pills/speed of years ago.  does that go away?  I will need neupogen shots four days a week next week and thanks to info here i broke through my panic and talked to provider and pharmacist  and i will not give myself the shots at $400 per shot, but will go in to the injection room to get them as this will then be covered better under my medical plan at a lower cost.  (I have no prescription drug coverage.)  Seems to me I should get a break for doing them myself, but our  health care system is pretty broken in a lot of ways.  I was also prescribed emend for nausea originally, but we switched that to generic stuff as each individual pill was $107!  If necessary, I will get it, but so far so good.  Hope all of you are having a good day and good sleep at night.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 07:24PM joyce1419 wrote: Thank you for the reply.  Yes, the waiting is the worst but it does give me a chance to sort out my questions and concerns. I am sorry that you have lympadema problems.  On the one hand I want all cancer cut out, but I am hoping the chemo will take care of it and that is what the oncolist will reassure me.  I just read that is not the gold standard to not check all available nodes and I freaked.  I am right handed, and already have right shoulder problems so I might go along with the new thinking as a gamble for less post treatment issues.  Hope all is well in Australia.  I loved my visit to Sydney, Melbourne and the GBR a few years ago.  A childhood dream that took decades to fulfill.

Posts.Content: joyce1419 wrote: I had a lumpectomy and sentinel node only removal  last week. the surgeon said the margins are clear enough.  smallest is 5 mm. he sees no need for further sugery of the breast.   however, the sentinel node is positive but does not feel any need for further surgery.  i do not get to see my oncologist for two weeks to discuss what next.   is it becoming standard practice to not remove other nodes?
